setup.question: How did Hendricks outfit the ship for war?
answers: She outfitted the ship for discovery, not war
She had additional screens installed to withstand combat

Text.text: I'd find it a bit surprising if there's a question with a false presupposition, but it does seem plausible in this case, so not betting hard on it.
At the start of the story, the warship Cleopatra was transferred to the department of research to run some tests (

). 
The Cleopatra reaches the base where it is fitted with screens. It is then explained by Ivy Hendricks that they want to make it a hyperspace ship

.
**Subsequently**, the communications come through that an invasion has happened and a war has begun.
Since the Cleopatra is a warship, the crew head into active duty despite the transfer. Line nos. confirm the ordering of these events.
The Cleopatra is the name of an old warship that has been retrofitted and upgraded, in part with this new screen system to detect enemy entities that would otherwise get lost in the warp.

Evidence & line #s align better with Debater A's version: I read the sentence at (2510–2523) as using "now" in contrast to before, with The Cleopatra being a warship only relevant to mention as it is about to be repurposed for the newly started war. But that doesn't quite mean it wasn't originally outfitted for war and not discovery; "research and development" or "innovations and tests" might equally apply to war.

A: can you show that the "hyper-ship" outfitting was for discovery and not war, Ivy = Hendricks, and/or there wasn't a war beforehand?

B: you seem to mean screens in the sense of displays showing views from telecameras in the warp. But this sounds different from screens for "withstanding combat." Can you explain the discrepancy?
1. Confirms both Ivy = Hendricks + the fact that Ivy intended to use the Cleopatra for hyperspace-related experiments

2. Here is a crew member (drunkenly) talking, expressing some frustration that they were doing some experimental testing for Ivy Hendricks when the Eridans _might_ attack Sol soon i.e. not yet. The Eridans are the ones who 'launch a major invasion' later in the story (as mentioned in my earlier argument).

The ship was transferred, but that is why it needed to be outfitted for war in the first place. Most of my evidence comes later in the story than As, after it was outfitted for war.

Here is the installation:
They help withstand combat when the

The screens are on the outside of the ship and have offensive capabilities to confuse the enemies and their weapons. 

A must prove it was outfitted for discovery, not just used for it. Outfitting is an active process. A new department isn't enough. A must show active tech changes.

I don't quite understand the burdens B is trying to impose on A. A is talking about why it was outfitted and not how it was used, whereas B is the one talking about use and not purpose. B, can you provide direct evidence that this was the *reason* it was outfitted with screens, and if not, explain why you can't provide such evidence?

A's quote from the crew member is pretty convincing. Why would they be saying that if it were outfitted for war? B, what's your explanation for this?

As an aside, it also feels like it would help if either debater can flesh things out a bit so I can better understand what these screens, or the hyper-ship outfitting, actually did.

Timeline: (1) Cleopatra was transferred to the research dept (2) Outfitting happens (3) War breaks out and the ship/crew go to war. 
I'm confused by B's last point. B provided evidence for how the screens were used in the war. I don't disagree with this. The question asks the intention why the outfitting was done in the first place which is because Ivy Hendricks intended to use the Cleopatra for hyperspace research (already established imo).

War breaks out while the crew meet Ivy so we don't get an explanation of how the outfitting would help in research beyond this -

Hyper-ship outfitting is a way of transportation that allows the Cleopatra to get to the battlefield. A does not dispute that the screens have an explicit war purpose.

The key part (and answer to A's previous quote) is that A's timeline is wrong. 3 and 2 are flipped. War broke out, then the Cleopatra was outfitted for combat:
Government gets intelligence for war:
Retrofit:
A's quote is banter between peers about how they are unprepared. It is not indicative of the ship outfitting. The fact is that the Cleopatra, after war breaks out, is outfitted for it

B's evidence continues to be very thin. I'm not totally satisfied with A's evidence, but B has failed to falsify any of their claims. The timeline provided by A did not actually help me, because it just recapitulated what they had already said. I was looking for more details on what the screens were intended to do w.r.t. 'discovery'. The idea that things would start disappearing after they set up the screens doesn't really make sense to me so I wanted more details on that. But at this point it seems not worth continuing the debate because B's arguments are so thin anyway.
Seems pretty clear cut to prove either answer, which are more is the question correct or not

Leaning A since they prove Hendricks' intent, which is a vital part of the question BUT just because it's a hypership doesn't prove that it was intended for discovery? Again, fast ships are probably also critical for war. 

Will swing B is B gives evidence that Hendricks herself is the 'we' their first evidence talks about.
Again, same concerns as above. Need B to prove Ivy personally outfitted the ship for war.
Seems like both A + B agree outfitting the ship happens early on the story, so I default to A's evidence which both is earlier and proves Ivy herself outfitted the ship for discovery.
Feel B can very easily be either proved or disproved with a simple quote.
A seems to be contradicting themselves, if the Cleopatra is in fact a warship then the ship must have been outfitted for war? One more round to clear up a potential misunderstanding on my part
B's quotes are pretty damning

answers.reason for outcome: The use of the screens is ambiguous.
I found Debater B's argument to get more confusing (+ hard to substantiate) as the debate went on, while Debater A's became clearer and better substantiated.
I think I had a different interpretation of the question.
both A + B agree outfitting the ship happens early on the story, so I default to A's evidence which both is earlier and proves Ivy herself outfitted the ship for discovery.

answers.interface: Sometimes selecting evidence across paragraphs doesn't work
answers.reason for outcome: The other option was pretty hard to argue for
